Detailed Description

connection datatype and related functions.

Enumeration Type Documentation

enum notes_protocols

Symbolic names representing notes protocols.

Enumerator:
NEWTS_PROTOCOL_NCP  The hypothetical Newts Client Protocol.

enum notes_standard_ports

Symbolic names representing the default ports for the various notes protocols.

Enumerator:
NEWTS_NCP_STANDARD_PORT  The default port for NCP.

Function Documentation

struct connection* connection_alloc ( void   )  [read]

Create a new struct connection.

Returns:
A newly allocated struct connection. This should be freed with connection_free when no longer needed.
See also:
connection_free

void connection_copy ( struct connection *  dest,
const struct connection *  source 
)

Duplicate an existing connection. This is a deep copy; strings from source will be copied, and dest will point to those copied strings, not the originals from source. This function is safe to use if overwriting existing values in dest.

Parameters:
dest The connection to copy values to.
source The connection to copy values from.
Side effects:
The values stored in dest will be modified. Additionally, if dest was previously populated, its existing string elements will be freed before being overwritten.

void connection_free ( struct connection *  conn  ) 

Deallocate connection.

Side effects:
connection will be invalidated, and should no longer be used.
See also:
connection_alloc

Return the protocol to use to access the notesfile specified by conn.

const unsigned short  new_port 
)

Modify conn to refer to a notesfile accessed with port new_port.

Side effects:
conn will be modified.

char* connection_system ( const struct connection *  conn  ) 

Return the system on which the notesfile specified by conn is found.

int connection_system_is_localhost ( const struct connection *  conn  ) 

Return TRUE if the notesfile specified by conn refers to a notesfile on localhost, or FALSE otherwise.

This is defined to be true if connection_system (conn) would return NULL, "", or "localhost".

FIXME: Obviously, this is a little braindead.
